title: Handling Life's Setbacks With Schizophrenia

content: Setbacks in life are inevitable. Just when you think everything is moving along smoothly, life throws you a curveball and disrupts your plans. Whether it’s a relationship issue, trouble at home, or something job-related, setbacks can be devastating.
But with schizophrenia, setbacks can also cause your symptoms to spiral out of control.

I’ve had a number of setbacks in life. I had financial struggles and was on the verge of bankruptcy. I experienced the loss of multiple romantic relationships. I had my share of rejection letters for scholarships and jobs that I applied for, and I was fired from a job.
None of these were wanted and they were difficult to navigate. There were times a setback completely knocked the wind out of me.
Even though I was medication-compliant, my symptoms were heightened. I’m fortunate to have protective factors and coping skills that help me manage stress, so my symptoms don’t resurface.

Protective factors include my support network. I tap into family, friends, and a team of psychiatric professionals to wrap me with support. They help me process what I’m going through so I don’t isolate myself and get lost in negative thoughts.

content: Through therapy, I learned the art of managing and regulating my emotions, to help keep a positive state of mind. Being able to problem-solve and plan next steps make me resilient. My ability to weigh options makes it possible for me to see I still have a future, despite what comes my way.

During rough patches, I use coping skills to stay centered. I listen to uplifting and positive music during my downtime to keep my spirits up. Creating art helps me relax and focus on something other than my troubles. I use journaling to transfer my thoughts and feelings to the page, reduce stress, and better understand the situation I’m in.

Having my cat, Loki, also helps. He gets me through setbacks as well. He gives me companionship; reduces my stress, anxiety, and depression; eases my loneliness; and encourages playfulness. Loki keeps me on my toes and makes me more responsible. I have a living being counting on me to survive and stay well.

content: It’d be nice if life moved along at a steady pace and I could avoid trouble. But that’s not how life works. Life, like mental health recovery, is made of hills and valleys. It’s not a smoothly paved road.
If you live with schizophrenia and you’re faced with a setback, know that you’re not alone. There are professional help, protective factors, and coping skills to help get you through.
Remember that despite our disorder,  we can be quite resilient and overcome whatever happens when we have the right kind of tools and support.
